dt: {bc}having high and often {d_link|capricious|capricious} standards {bc}difficult to please

dt.t: critics … so {wi}fastidious{/wi} that they can talk only to a small circle of initiates

quotes.t: My mother had always been the most {qword}fastidious{/qword} and organized of people—a wet ring left on her coffee table by a glass could drive her to distraction.
"I'll stop off and get us a sandwich," said Matthew.  … Tony, a {qword}fastidious{/qword} eater, sighed.
Though he prides himself on being hip, he is too {qword}fastidious{/qword} to do anything dangerous or dirty.

et: Middle English, from Latin {it}fastidiosus{/it}, from {it}fastidium{/it} disgust, probably from {it}fastus{/it} arrogance (probably akin to Latin {it}fastigium{/it} top) + {it}taedium{/it} irksomeness {ma}{mat|tedium|}{/ma}
shortdef: showing or demanding excessive delicacy or care
reflecting a meticulous, sensitive, or demanding attitude
having high and often capricious standards : difficult to please
